Dept. of Energy,</subfield><subfield code="c">2006.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="264" ind1=" " ind2="2"><subfield code="a">Oak Ridge, Tenn. :</subfield><subfield code="b">Distributed by the Office of Scientific and Technical Information, U.S. Dept. of Energy.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="300" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">82 pages :</subfield><subfield code="b">digital, PDF file.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="336" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">text</subfield><subfield code="b">txt</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacontent</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="337" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">computer</subfield><subfield code="b">c</subfield><subfield code="2">rdamedia</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="338" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">online resource</subfield><subfield code="b">cr</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacarrier</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Published through SciTech Connect.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">05/01/2006.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">"fermilab-thesis-2006-10"</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Hamilton, Andrew.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="506" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Free-to-read</subfield><subfield code="f">Unrestricted online access</subfield><subfield code="2">star</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="520" ind1="3" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">This thesis presents two exclusive production processes in p{bar p} collisions at √s = 1.96 TeV, using the Collider Detector Facility at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. An observation of exclusive e⁺e⁻ production through γγ → e⁺e⁻ is presented, as well as evidence for exclusive production of γγ through gg → γγ (via a quark loop). The exclusive e⁺e⁻ production observation is based on 16 candidate events, with a background estimate of 2.1{sub -0.3}{sup +0.7}. Each event has an e⁺e⁻ pair (E{sub T} (e) > 5 GeV, </subfield><subfield code=" ">< 2) and nothing else observable in the CDF detector. The measured cross section is 1.6{sub -0.3}{sup +0.5}(stat) ± 0.3(sys) pb, while the predicted cross section is 1.711 ± 0.008 pb. The kinematic properties of the events are consistent with the predictions of the LPAIR Monte Carlo. The evidence for exclusive γγ production consists of 3 candidate events, with a background estimate of 0.0{sub -0.0}{sup +0.2} events. Each event has two photons (E{sub T}γ) > 5 GeV, </subfield><subfield code=" ">< 1 and nothing else observable in the CDF detector. The measured cross section for these events is 0.14{sub -0.04}{sup +0.14}(stat) ± (sys) pb. It agrees with the theoretical prediction of 0.04 pb with a factor 3 to 5 theoretical uncertainty.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="b">AC02-76CH03000</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="650" ind1=" " ind2="7"><subfield code="a">Particle Accelerators.</subfield><subfield code="2">edbsc</subfield></datafield><datafield all_text_timv: Exclusive interactions in p anti-p collisions at s**(1/2) = 1.96 TeV [electronic resource]. Washington, D.C. : United States. Dept. of Energy, 2006. Oak Ridge, Tenn. : Distributed by the Office of Scientific and Technical Information, U.S. Dept. of Energy. 82 pages : digital, PDF file. text txt rdacontent computer c rdamedia online resource cr rdacarrier Published through SciTech Connect. 05/01/2006. "fermilab-thesis-2006-10" Hamilton, Andrew. Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star This thesis presents two exclusive production processes in p{bar p} collisions at √s = 1.96 TeV, using the Collider Detector Facility at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. An observation of exclusive e⁺e⁻ production through γγ → e⁺e⁻ is presented, as well as evidence for exclusive production of γγ through gg → γγ (via a quark loop). The exclusive e⁺e⁻ production observation is based on 16 candidate events, with a background estimate of 2.1{sub -0.3}{sup +0.7}. Each event has an e⁺e⁻ pair (E{sub T} (e) > 5 GeV,  < 2) and nothing else observable in the CDF detector. The measured cross section is 1.6{sub -0.3}{sup +0.5}(stat) ± 0.3(sys) pb, while the predicted cross section is 1.711 ± 0.008 pb. The kinematic properties of the events are consistent with the predictions of the LPAIR Monte Carlo. The evidence for exclusive γγ production consists of 3 candidate events, with a background estimate of 0.0{sub -0.0}{sup +0.2} events. Each event has two photons (E{sub T}γ) > 5 GeV,  < 1 and nothing else observable in the CDF detector. The measured cross section for these events is 0.14{sub -0.04}{sup +0.14}(stat) ± (sys) pb. It agrees with the theoretical prediction of 0.04 pb with a factor 3 to 5 theoretical uncertainty.
